title: How to Make a Heart Shaped Cutter from a Plastic Straw

steps.headline: Flatten one end of the straw.
steps.description: At this flattened end, measure out a length of about 1cm (0.39"). The straw will be used on food so avoid using any mark that cannot be removed.

steps.headline: Cut the straw, as shown in the diagram.
steps.description: Make an incision about 1cm (0.39") from the end. Only cut a slit into the straw, not all the way around. The depth of the cut is 1/2 the width of the flattened straw.

steps.headline: Find the point of the incision.
steps.description:
There, bend the end piece inward across the top. You are aiming to make a heart shape, as depicted in the image. On the short side of the cut straw, the flattened fold is reversed in direction. The fold will be at the center of the straw. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Cutter-s_858.JPG/460px-Cutter-s_858.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/49/Cutter-s_858.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":461,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":761.4048059149723,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}Looking at the heart shape from the top.

steps.headline: Slide a thinner straw inside the cut straw.
steps.description: Move the thinner straw up to the place where the heart has been created. It is positioned on top of the heart or the 'v' part of the shape. This supports the shape of the heart when it is used. This inner straw will become the tool by which you push out the heart-shaped food piece.

steps.headline: Find the food that you'd like to make into heart shapes.
steps.description:
Push the heart shape of the straw into the food. Pull it out when the food has been cut and is sitting inside the straw. Slide the thinner straw out and use it to push out the cut heart piece. Cheese makes an excellent choice as it is soft and easy to cut. Dipping the tip into a little vegetable oil can make it easier to slide the cut heart out. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Heart-cheese_910.JPG/460px-Heart-cheese_910.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/f/fb/Heart-cheese_910.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"} Slice the food more thinly if it is thick. The thickness of the food should be only as deep as the heart cutter. If the food is dense, make as thin a slice as possible. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/b6/Slice-cheese_666.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/b6/Slice-cheese_666.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":222,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":367.23514211886305,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}

steps.headline: Push out the heart shape.
steps.description: Make use of the slender straw you inserted earlier to release the food piece from the straw. Pull it back and push the food out of the straw.

steps.headline: Make heart shapes within hearts.
steps.description: Experiment by cutting heart shapes in different straw sizes. Choose straws at least three times the diameter of the smaller straw to get the best contrast.

steps.headline: Try using the straw for sauces, too.
steps.description:
Make a hole in a food and squeeze sauce or jam into the space. Simply press the straw with a heart-shaped end into the food and pull out the food piece. With the heart-shaped hole, fill it with another food. For example, the egg image shows ketchup squeezed into the heart-shaped holes. How about strawberry jam squeezed into heart-shaped cut in a sweet cake? Make patterns like lacey edges or strips of hearts. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/HeartBreadPie_300.jpg/460px-HeartBreadPie_300.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c5/HeartBreadPie_300.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}

text:
Flatten one end of the straw. At this flattened end, measure out a length of about 1cm (0.39"). The straw will be used on food so avoid using any mark that cannot be removed. Cut the straw, as shown in the diagram. Make an incision about 1cm (0.39") from the end. Only cut a slit into the straw, not all the way around. The depth of the cut is 1/2 the width of the flattened straw. Find the point of the incision. There, bend the end piece inward across the top. You are aiming to make a heart shape, as depicted in the image. On the short side of the cut straw, the flattened fold is reversed in direction. The fold will be at the center of the straw. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Cutter-s_858.JPG/460px-Cutter-s_858.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/49/Cutter-s_858.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":461,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":761.4048059149723,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"}Looking at the heart shape from the top. Slide a thinner straw inside the cut straw. Move the thinner straw up to the place where the heart has been created. It is positioned on top of the heart or the 'v' part of the shape. This supports the shape of the heart when it is used. This inner straw will become the tool by which you push out the heart-shaped food piece. Find the food that you'd like to make into heart shapes. Push the heart shape of the straw into the food. Pull it out when the food has been cut and is sitting inside the straw. Slide the thinner straw out and use it to push out the cut heart piece. Cheese makes an excellent choice as it is soft and easy to cut. Dipping the tip into a little vegetable oil can make it easier to slide the cut heart out. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fb/Heart-cheese_910.JPG/460px-Heart-cheese_910.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/f/fb/Heart-cheese_910.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

"} Slice the food more thinly if it is thick. The thickness of the food should be only as deep as the heart cutter. If the food is dense, make as thin a slice as possible. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/b6/Slice-cheese_666.png","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/b6/Slice-cheese_666.png","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":222,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":367.23514211886305,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

Image from: Uploader
License: Public Domain

"} Push out the heart shape. Make use of the slender straw you inserted earlier to release the food piece from the straw. Pull it back and push the food out of the straw. Make heart shapes within hearts. Experiment by cutting heart shapes in different straw sizes. Choose straws at least three times the diameter of the smaller straw to get the best contrast. Try using the straw for sauces, too. Make a hole in a food and squeeze sauce or jam into the space. Simply press the straw with a heart-shaped end into the food and pull out the food piece. With the heart-shaped hole, fill it with another food. For example, the egg image shows ketchup squeezed into the heart-shaped holes. How about strawberry jam squeezed into heart-shaped cut in a sweet cake? Make patterns like lacey edges or strips of hearts. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c5/HeartBreadPie_300.jpg/460px-HeartBreadPie_300.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/c/c5/HeartBreadPie_300.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"
